unnormalised: The day results were announced, my heart felt like it was doing the bhangra. I’d spent countless nights studying, fueled by chai and the dreams of getting into a good engineering college. My parents, especially mummyji, had high expectations, you see. Getting a good score in the CBSE 12th boards was like climbing Mount Everest. The news spread like wildfire through our colony in Delhi: 10 AM, results online.
normalised: The day results were announced, my heart felt like it was doing the bhangra. I’d spent countless nights studying, fueled by chai and the dreams of getting into a good engineering college. My parents, especially mummyji, had high expectations, you see. Getting a good score in the C-B-S-E twelfth boards was like climbing Mount Everest. The news spread like wildfire through our colony in Delhi: ten A-M, results online.

unnormalised: I logged in, fingers trembling. My roll number, 1234567890, felt like a lifetime achievement award just to type. The screen flickered, and there it was. English: 92/100. Not bad, I thought. Maths: 98/100. YES! Physics: 95/100. Chemistry: 96/100. Computer Science: 99/100. The aggregate percentage flashed – 96%. I’d done it.
normalised: I logged in, fingers trembling. My roll number, one two three four five six seven eight nine zero, felt like a lifetime achievement award just to type. The screen flickered, and there it was. English: ninety two divided by one hundred. Not bad, I thought. Maths: ninety eight divided by one hundred. YES! Physics: ninety five divided by one hundred. Chemistry: ninety six divided by one hundred. Computer Science: ninety nine divided by one hundred. The aggregate percentage flashed – ninety six percent. I’d done it.

unnormalised: The wave of relief was immense. I remember shouting so loud that even the neighbours probably heard. Papa, who's usually the stoic type, gave me a rare, proud pat on the back. Mummyji, of course, started distributing mithai to everyone she could find. It was a proper celebration, complete with loud Bollywood music.
normalised: The wave of relief was immense. I remember shouting so loud that even the neighbours probably heard. Papa, who's usually the stoic type, gave me a rare, proud pat on the back. Mummyji, of course, started distributing mithai to everyone she could find. It was a proper celebration, complete with loud Bollywood music.

unnormalised: But the real challenge was just beginning. 96% was good, great even, but the cutoffs for IIT Delhi were always ridiculously high. Last year, the closing rank for Computer Science was something like 500. My JEE Main score, which I got a few weeks before, was decent, but not stellar – AIR 2500. The pressure to perform well in the JEE Advanced felt like carrying the weight of the world.
normalised: But the real challenge was just beginning. ninety six percent was good, great even, but the cutoffs for I-I-T Delhi were always ridiculously high. Last year, the closing rank for Computer Science was something like five hundred. My J-E-E Main score, which I got a few weeks before, was decent, but not stellar – A-I-R two thousand five hundred. The pressure to perform well in the J-E-E Advanced felt like carrying the weight of the world.

unnormalised: I spent the next few weeks prepping like a machine. Solving problem after problem, going through past papers, and attending endless coaching classes. Finally, the day arrived. I sat in the exam hall, attempting question 1 with focus. After what felt like an eternity, the scores were released on June 14, 2023. I got a rank of 750. Not amazing, but enough!
normalised: I spent the next few weeks prepping like a machine. Solving problem after problem, going through past papers, and attending endless coaching classes. Finally, the day arrived. I sat in the exam hall, attempting question one with focus. After what felt like an eternity, the scores were released on fourteenth June two thousand and twenty three. I got a rank of seven hundred and fifty. Not amazing, but enough!

unnormalised: Ultimately, I didn't get into Computer Science at IIT Delhi. But, I did manage to get into IIT Roorkee for Electrical Engineering. It taught me that hard work definitely matters, and even a CBSE score of 96% doesn't guarantee everything, but it sure opens doors. And honestly, that celebratory mithai tasted pretty sweet.
normalised: Ultimately, I didn't get into Computer Science at I-I-T Delhi. But, I did manage to get into I-I-T Roorkee for Electrical Engineering. It taught me that hard work definitely matters, and even a C-B-S-E score of ninety six percent doesn't guarantee everything, but it sure opens doors. And honestly, that celebratory mithai tasted pretty sweet.
